Coleman stole money and buried it in a bottle in Terry's garden.
====Rose Hill==== * George Mitton – 1788 – Hanged at Rose Hill ([[Parramatta]]) for robbery.<ref>http://setis.library.usyd.edu.au/ozlit/pdf/colacc2.pdf</ref> * William Harris – 28 October 1790 – Broke into a house in Rose Hill and assaulted one of the occupants, stole three pounds of beef and one pound of flour, a frock and a book. He was publicly hanged at Rose Hill. * Edward Wildblood – 28 October 1790 – A co-offender with the aforementioned William Harris, he was convicted of breaking into a house in Rose Hill, assaulting one of the occupants and stealing three pounds of beef and one pound of flour, a frock and a book. He was publicly hanged at Rose Hill.
====Parramatta==== * James Derry – 19 September 1796 – Hanged at Parramatta for robbing the public stores. * Matthew McNally – 1 December 1796 – Hanged at Parramatta for robbing the public stores.<ref name="collinsd">{{cite book|last1=Collins|first1=David|editor1-last=Flannery|editor1-first=Tim|editor1-link=Tim Flannery|title=The Birth of Sydney|date=1999|publisher=Text Publishing|location=Melbourne|isbn=9781921776588|page=148|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=2tReMxRJTAEC&pg=PA148|accessdate=18 February 2018|chapter=The object of much terror}}</ref> * Thomas Doyle – 1 December 1796 – Hanged at Parramatta for robbing the public stores.<ref name="collinsd"/> * Simon Taylor – 20 May 1799 – Hanged at Parramatta for the murder of his wife Anne Taylor. * Richard Weston – May or June 1800 – Hanged at Parramatta for vagrancy and theft. * Charles Hill – 8 March 1804 – Freeman who participated in the Castle Hill Rebellion. Hanged at Parramatta * Samuel Humes – 8 March 1804 – Convict, a principal and informant who participated in the Castle Hill Rebellion. Executed at Parramatta, then gibbeted * John Place – 8 March 1804 – Convict who participated in the Castle Hill Rebellion. Hanged at Parramatta. * Patrick McDermot – 19 May 1806 – Hanged at Parramatta for burglary from the house of Matthew Pearce at [[Seven Hills, New South Wales|Seven Hills]] and theft of clothing items. * John Kenny – 24 January 1807 – Hanged and gibbetted at the scene of the crime in Parramatta for the murder of Mary Smith. * Michael Bagan – 20 June 1808 – Entered the house of Jane Codd near Parramatta, assaulted her and stole items from her home. Hanged at the Parramatta brickfields. * Felix Donnelly – 20 June 1808 – Entered the house of Jane Codd near Parramatta, assaulted her and stole items from her home. Hanged at the Parramatta brickfields. * John Dunn – 25 August 1811 – Hanged at Parramatta for the murder of Mary Rowe, his body was handed over to the medical officer at Parramatta General Hospital for dissection and anatomisation. * Pearce Conden – 24 March 1813 – Publicly hanged at the site of the crime in George St Parramatta for the murder of Joseph Sutton. Body handed over for dissection and anatomisation. * Thomas Mahony – 24 March 1813 – Publicly hanged at the site of the crime in George St Parramatta for the murder of Joseph Sutton. Body handed over for dissection and anatomisation. * Matthew Craven – 16 October 1826 – Publicly hanged outside Parramatta for 'divers robberies'.<ref>{{cite news|title=29th September 1826|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/31757862|publisher=The Monitor|date=29 September 1826}}</ref> * Thomas Cavanaugh – 16 October 1826 – Publicly hanged outside Parramatta for armed robberies.<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Bushrangers|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/37071477|publisher=The Australian|date=18 October 1826}}</ref> * Thomas (John) Ashton – 2 December 1829 – Hanged at Parramatta for rape of ten-year-old Elizabeth Price.
====Castle Hill==== * Patrick Gannon – 23 March 1803 – Hanged at [[Castle Hill, New South Wales|Castle Hill]] for rape, attempted murder and robbery. * Francis Simpson – 23 March 1803 – Hanged along with Patrick Gannon at Castle Hill for robbery. * John Lynch – 27 September 1803 – Hanged at Castle Hill for the assault and robbery of Samuel Phelps at Hawkesbury.<ref name="Lynch-Tracey">{{cite news|title=Execution at Castle-Hill|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/page/5775|accessdate=15 September 2016|work=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser|date=2 October 1803|page=3}}</ref> * James Tracey – 27 September 1803 – Hanged at Castle Hill for the assault and robbery of Samuel Phelps at Hawkesbury.<ref name="Lynch-Tracey"/> * William Johnston – 9 March 1804 – Convict, a principal along with Phillip Cunningham in the Castle Hill Rebellion. Executed at Castle Hill, then gibbeted. * John Neal – 9 March 1804 – Convict who participated in the Castle Hill Rebellion. Hanged at the Government Farm, Castle Hill. * George Harrington – 9 March 1804 – Convict who participated in the Castle Hill Rebellion. Hanged at the Government Farm, Castle Hill.
====Hawkesbury & Windsor==== * Thomas McLaughlane (the elder) – 7 October 1803 – Hanged at Hawkesbury, for robbery with violence at the house of John Palmer at Hawkesbury.<ref>{{cite news|title=Criminal Court|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/625788/5770|accessdate=15 September 2016|work=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser|date=26 September 1803|page=2}}</ref> * Phillip Cunningham – 5 March 1804 – Convict, leader of the [[Castle Hill Rebellion]]. Summarily hanged on the steps of the government storehouse at Greenhills (present day Windsor). * James Davis – 19 June 1810 – Hanged at Portland Head (Hawkesbury) for burglary from the house of John Cox. * Thomas Begley – 31 August 1829 – Hanged at Windsor for burglary at Mulgoa. * Michael Rafter – 29 January 1830 – Hanged at Windsor for a litany of burglaries in the Portland Head district. * John Smith – 29 January 1830 – Hanged at Windsor for rape of his seven-year-old daughter. * John Tiernan – 25 August 1830 – Hanged at Windsor for highway robbery, horse theft and stealing. Aged seventeen, Tiernan objected to being interrupted in his prayers on the scaffold and wrestled the executioner over the edge of the platform.
====Newcastle==== * John Pagan – 7 January 1820 – Hanged at Newcastle for the murder of James White. * William Smith – 7 January 1820 – Hanged at Newcastle for the murder of James White.
====Burwood==== * Daniel Watkins – 16 October 1826 – Publicly hanged at [[Burwood, New South Wales|Burwood]] for the armed robbery of Thomas Bartie Clay at Burwood. * Thomas Mustin (Muston) – 16 October 1826 – Publicly hanged at Burwood for robbery and putting in fear at the house of Richard Morgan on the Liverpool Road. * John Brown – 16 October 1826 – Publicly hanged at Burwood for robbery and putting in fear at the house of Richard Morgan on the Liverpool Road.
====Bankstown==== * Patrick Sullivan – 18 October 1826 – Publicly hanged on gallows constructed in Bankstown ('Irish Town', now Bass Hill) for [[bushranging]]. * James Moran – 18 October 1826 – Publicly hanged on gallows constructed in Bankstown ('Irish Town', now Bass Hill) for [[bushranging]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Executions|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/31757921|accessdate=7 October 2016|publisher=The Monitor|date=20 October 1826}}</ref>
====Sydney Gaol==== * John Brunger (also called Brugan/Burgen) – 18 Apr 1829 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for the murder of William Perfoot (also called Parfitt) at Moreton Bay.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boggoroad.blogspot.com.au/2015/07/hanged-dissected-for-picking-mans-brains.html |title=Life & Death in the Sunshine State: Hanged & Dissected... For Picking a Man's Brains |publisher=Boggoroad (Blogspot) |date=July 2015|accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://research.forbessociety.org.au/record/963 |title=NSW Capital Convictions Database |publisher=Research.forbessociety.org.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Thomas Matthews – 18 April 1829 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for the murder of Connolly, a fellow work-gang member, at Moreton Bay. * Thomas Allen – 18 April 1829 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for the murder of Connolly, a fellow work-gang member, at Moreton Bay. * James Naughton – 25 May 1829 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for the murder of Elizabeth Watson. He was previously charged, with Edward Gorman, with murder in 1823.<ref name=gorman/><ref>{{cite news|title=Execution |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/2192514/497415|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser|date=26 May 1829|page=2}}</ref> * George Williams – 22 October 1829 – Hanged in the yard of Sydney Gaol for the highway robbery, assault and battery of William Hickey<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/32072666|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=The Sydney Mirror|date=26 October 1829|page=3}}</ref>
====Campbelltown==== * John Holmes – 21 August 1829 – Hanged at Campbelltown for setting fire to a barn belonging to James Benn at Campbelltown. * Richard McCann – 6 February 1830 – Hanged at Campbelltown for theft, assault and putting in fear in the Goulburn district * Thomas Beasley - 8 February 1830 - Hanged at Campbelltown for burglary with assault in the Airds district * Joseph Moorbee (Mowerby, ''alias'' Nuttall) - 8 February 1830 - Hanged at Campbelltown for burglary with assault in the Airds district * Mark Byfield – 8 March 1830 – Hanged at Sydney for the theft of a silver watch<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/36864568|publisher=The Australian|date=10 March 1830}}</ref> * Broger – 30 August 1830 – Indigenous. Ann's husband John had been stabbed to death by one of their servants, Edward Tufts, earlier that year. * William Wilkins – 4 September 1838 – Hanged at Sydney for assault and robbery of Thomas Humphries near Maitland. * William Worthington ("Bumblefoot") – 4 September 1838 – Hanged at Sydney for the axe murder of Jack Swan at Port Macquarie.<ref>{{cite news|title=Law Intelligence|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/12856943|publisher=Sydney Herald|date=10 August 1838}}</ref> * William Hawkins – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]].<ref>The Sydney Monitor and Commercial Advertiser Mon 17 Dec 1838 p 2 https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/32162238</ref> * John Johnson – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]]. * Edward Foley – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]]. * Jim Oates – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]]. * James Parry – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]]. * Charlie Kilmeister – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]]. * John Russell – 18 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney Gaol for his part in the [[Myall Creek Massacre]]. * William Price – 21 December 1838 – Hanged at Sydney for the murder of John "My Lord" Dunn in Sorrell Street Parramatta. The victim was well known in the district at the time; he was seventy years old, a convict who had been in the colony thirty years, "very deformed" and less than a metre tall.<ref>{{cite news|title=Parramatta, Inhuman Murder|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/32161160|publisher=Sydney Monitor|date=3 September 1838}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=My Lord ===NSW part three, 1840s (61 listed - incomplete)===
* John (or James) Hunt ("The Doctor") – 10 March 1840 – Hanged at Sydney for murder of Dan McCarthy at Regentville * Thomas Whitton – 19 March 1840 – Publicly hanged at Goulburn for the murder of John Hawker and arson at Oak Park, Crookwell. ===NSW part six, 1870s (25 listed - discrepancy with statistics by decade)===
* John Baker - 1871 - Bushranger hanged at Bathurst for murder and other crimes. A partner of Wiliam Bertam who was hung in Toowoomba 29.8.1870. They stuck up Mount Murchison Station, Cobham's station and a Poolamacca resident and stole horses, etc. Also committed other robberies on the road and entered homes; in Oct 1869 on the Barrier Ranges they bailed up a hawker, Charles Young, whom they murdered.<ref>NSW Capital Convictions Database http://research.forbessociety.org.au/record/2477</ref> * Robert Campbell (''alias'' Palmer) – 10 January 1871 – Hanged at Wagga Wagga for the murder of John and Louis Pohlman at Yanco. * Chong Gow – 6 June 1871 – Hanged at [[Deniliquin]] for the murder of Tommy Ah Gun at Hay. * Michael McMahon – 12 December 1871 – Hanged at Maitland for the murder of Jack Jones at Hall's Creek. * Thomas Kelly – 2 January 1872 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the attempted murder of Superintendent William McLaren at [[Parramatta Correctional Centre|Parramatta Gaol]]. * George Robert Nichols (The Parramatta River Murders) – 18 June 1872 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of William Percy Walker (and John Bridger) in upper Sydney Harbour. * Alfred Lester (''alias'' Froude)(The Parramatta River Murders) – 18 June 1872 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of William Percy Walker (and John Bridger) in upper Sydney Harbour. * John Conn – 11 June 1872 – Hanged at Bathurst for the murder of Aveline Littler near Wyndeyer. * William McCrow – 8 April 1873 – Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of Margaret Ward at a residence on the corner of Crown and Stanley streets, Woolloomooloo. * John Scource – 8 April 1873 – Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of Elizabeth Lee on Sydney Harbour. * Julius Krauss (also called William Cross) – 1 July 1873 – Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of Captain John Longmuir on board ''HMS Rifleman''. * Henry Vincent Jarvis – 23 December 1873 – Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of James Muggeridge on the Orange-Bathurst Road near Evans Plains Creek. * John Hawthorne (''alias'' Perry, real name Sherrin) – 19 May 1874 – Bushranger. Believed to have committed at least four murders. Hanged at Goulburn for the robbery & attempted murder of James Slocombe near Wheeo. * John Glover – 19 May 1874 – Hanged at Goulburn for the murder of William Piety at Bolaro, near Adaminaby. * Gottlieb Eichhorn – 23 June 1874 – Hanged at Armidale Gaol for the rape of seventy-two-year-old Eliza Chapman at Saumarez Ponds. Mrs Chapman died from the injuries received. Eichhorn was sixteen at the time of the crime.<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Eichhorn|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/188979762|publisher=The Armidale Express and New England General Advertiser|date=26 June 1874}}</ref> * John McGrath – 10 September 1875 – Indigenous. Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for rape of Sarah Murfin at Warragubra, near Bega. * George Rope – 7 December 1875 – Hanged at Mudgee Gaol for the murder of his sister-in-law Hannah Rope at Lawson's Creek. * Ah Chong – 18 April 1876 – Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of Po Tie at Parramatta Gaol. * George Pitt – 21 June 1876 – Hanged at Mudgee for the murder of Ann Martin at Guntawang. * Michael Connelly – 28 June 1876 – Hanged at Tamworth Gaol for the murder of his wife Mary Connelly at Carroll Gap. * Daniel Boon – 19 July 1876 – Hanged at Wagga Wagga for the murder of Alexander McMullan at North Wagga. * Thomas Newman – 29 May 1877 – Hanged at [[Old Dubbo Gaol]] for the murder of a child, Mary-Ann McGregor, near Coonabarabran.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70601596 |title=02 Jun 1877 – The Execution of Newman at Dubbo. – Trove |publisher=Nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Peter Murdoch (Murdick, ''alias'' Higgins) – 18 December 1877 – Hanged at Wagga Wagga for the murder of Henry Ford near Cartwright's Hill. * Ing Chee – 28 May 1878 – Hanged at Goulburn Gaol for the murder of Li Dock in Goulburn. * Alfred – 10 June 1879 – Indigenous. Hanged at Mudgee for the rape of Jane Dowd at Three Mile Flat, near Wellington.
===NSW part seven, 1880s (26 listed - complete)===
* Andrew George Scott ([[Captain Moonlite]]) – 20 January 1880 – (Bushranger) Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of Constable Webb-Bowen at Wantabadgery. * Thomas Rogan – 20 January 1880 – (Bushranger) A member of the Moonlite Gang, hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the murder of Constable Webb-Bowen at Wantabadgery. * Albert – 26 May 1880 – Indigenous stockman, hanged at [[Old Dubbo Gaol]] for the shooting murders of Nugle Jack and Sally at a camp at [[Baradine]].<ref name="dailyliberal.com.au">{{cite web|author=HEATHER CROSBY14 Feb 2015, 4 a.m. |url=http://www.dailyliberal.com.au/story/2882294/gaol-has-lengthy-history-of-dead-inside-its-walls-photos/ |title=Gaol has lengthy history of dead inside its walls |PHOTOS |publisher=Daily Liberal |date=2015-02-14 |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Daniel King – 11 June 1880 – Hanged at Tamworth Gaol for the murder of Lizzie Hart (''alias'' Rolk, ''alias'' Betts) at Tamworth. * William Brown – 29 March 1881 – Hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the rape of his twelve-year-old daughter Ann at Yappa Brush, The Bight, across the Manning from Wingham. * Henry Wilkinson – 1 June 1881 – Hanged at Albury Gaol for the murder of Mary Pumpa at Lyster's Gap, near Jindera. * John McGuane – 22 November 1882 – Hanged at Armidale for the murder of Thomas Smith at Inverell.<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of McGuan|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/107999033|publisher=Evening News|date=22 November 1882}}</ref> * Charles Cunningham – 29 November 1882 – Hanged at Goulburn for the attempted murder of his warder Walter Izard at Berrima Gaol. "His last moments were marked by the expression of undiminished hatred to authority, which he personified to Her Majesty the Queen."<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Charles Cunningham|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/103795342|publisher=Goulburn Herald|date=30 November 1882}}</ref> * Henry Tester – 7 December 1882 – Hanged at Deniliquin for the murder of seven-year-old Louisa Preston at [[Moira, New South Wales|Moira]]. * George Ruxbourne – 23 May 1883 – Hanged at Armidale for the murder of Jimmy Young at Armidale.<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution at Armidale|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/110312288|publisher=The Bega Gazette and Eden District or Southern Coast Advertiser|date=2 June 1883}}</ref> * William Rice- 23 April 1884 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of James Griffin at 51 Phelps St, [[Surry Hills]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Jealousy And Murder|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/18924595|publisher=The Maitland Mercury and Hunter River General Advertiser|date=4 March 1884}}</ref> * Joseph Cordini – 13 June 1884 – Hanged at Deniliquin Gaol for the murder of George Mizon on the Hay road outside ([[Bushranger]]) A member of the Moonlite Gang, hanged at Darlinghurst Gaol for the attempted murder of William Roberts at [[Parramatta Correctional Centre|Parramatta Gaol]]. * Matthew Friske – 10 December 1885 – Hanged at Grafton Gaol for the murder of Matt Matteson at [[Coffs Harbour]]. * William Liddiard – 8 June 1886 – Hanged at Grafton for the murder of Pat Noonan at [[Wardell, New South Wales|Wardell]]. * Alfred Reynolds – 8 October 1886 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of his wife Rhoda at Gowrie St, Newtown. * Robert Read – 7 January 1887 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for his involvement in the [[Mount Rennie rape case]]. * George Duffy - 7 January 1887 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for his involvement in the [[Mount Rennie rape case]]. * William Boyce - 7 January 1887 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for his involvement in the [[Mount Rennie rape case]]. * Joseph Martin - 7 January 1887 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for his involvement in the [[Mount Rennie rape case]]. * John Creighan (''alias'' Grace) – 29 May 1888 – Hanged at Armidale for the murder of Jack Stapleton at [[Hillgrove, New South Wales|Hillgrove]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Grace|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/98448897|publisher=Goulburn Evening Penny Post|date=31 May 1888}}</ref> * Robert Hewart – 11 September 1888 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Thomas Park in a cell at the Central Police Court. * [[Louisa Collins]] – 22 January 1889 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the poisoning of her husband at Botany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64426428?searchTerm=louisa%20collins&searchLimits=l-decade=188%7C%7C%7Cl-month=01%7C%7C%7Cl-year=1889%7C%7Cl-category=Article |title=29 Jan 1889 – The Traralgon Record – Trove |publisher=Nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> She was the last woman hanged in New South Wales. * James Morrison – 19 July 1889 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Constable David Sutherland in Macleay St, Potts Point. * Thomas Riley – 6 November 1889 – Hanged at Wagga Wagga for the murder of Christian Eppel on the Wagga Common.
===NSW part eight, 1890s (22 listed - incomplete)===
* Albert Schmidt – 18 November 1890 – Hanged at Wagga Wagga for the murder of John Young Taylor near Old Junee. Believed to have committed at least two other murders. * Lars Peter Hansen – 2 June 1891 – Hanged at [[Old Dubbo Gaol]] for the murder of Charles Duncker on the Peak Hill road.<ref name="dailyliberal.com.au"/> * Maurice Dalton – 17 November 1891 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of his wife Catherine at 1 Foveaux St [[Surry Hills]]. * Harold Dutton Mallalieu – 26 November 1891 – Hanged at [[Old Dubbo Gaol]] for the murder of Jerome Casey on the Moonagee Road near Nyngan.<ref name="capitalpunishmentuk.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalpunishmentuk.org/aus1900.html |title=Australian executions 1870 – 1967 |publisher=Capitalpunishmentuk.org |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Jimmy Tong – 29 November 1892 – Hanged at Armidale for the murder of Harry Hing at Walcha.<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Jimmy Tong|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/189978256|publisher=Armidale Express|date=2 December 1892}}</ref> * Edward Smedley – 14 June 1893 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of his wife Phoebe at Qurindi. This hanging was mishandled and Smedley suffocated to death on the rope. * George Archer – 11 July 1893 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Emma Harrison at a house on the corner of Burton and Bourke streets, Darlinghurst. * [[John and Sarah Makin|John Makin]] – 15 August 1893 – ("The Macdonaldtown Baby Farmer"). Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of the infant Horace Murray. * Woy Hoy (Jimmy Ah Hoy) – 24 November 1893 – Hanged at Mudgee for the murder of Ah Fook in Lewis St, Mudgee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution at Mudgee|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/112933788|publisher=Evening News|date=25 November 1893}}</ref> * Herbert Edward 'Bertie' Glasson (sometimes Edwin Hubert) – 29 November 1893 – Hanged at Bathurst for the murder of John William Phillips and Frances Letitia 'Fanny' Cavanough at Carcoar on 23 September 1893. Advertiser (Qld. : 1861 - 1908), 24 October, p. 3. , viewed 05 Aug 2018, http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article123342712</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Previous hangings |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/158531361 |accessdate=14 September 2016|work=The National Advocate|date=21 December 1916|location=Bathurst, NSW|page=2}}</ref> * Charles Montgomery – 31 May 1894 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the attempted murder of Constable Fred Bowden near the corner of Bridge and Macquarie streets. * Thomas Williams – 31 May 1894 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the attempted murder of Constable Fred Bowden near the corner of Bridge and Macquarie streets. * Alexander Lee – 20 July 1894 – Hanged at Tamworth for the murder of William McKay at the CBC bank at [[Barraba, New South Wales|Barraba]]. * John Cummins – 20 July 1894 – Hanged at Tamworth for the murder of William McKay at the CBC bank at [[Barraba, New South Wales|Barraba]]. * Frederick Paton (''alias'' Frederick Dennis) – 11 December 1894 – Hanged at [[Bathurst Gaol]] for the murder of John Hall at Fifield on 6 May 1894.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article156322269?searchTerm=frederick paton&searchLimits=]</ref> * Alfred Grenon – 7 February 1895 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the attempted murder of Thomas Heavey at Elizabeth Bay. * Thomas Meredith Sheridan – 7 January 1896 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Jessie Nicholls, who died at Castlereagh St from the effects of an illegal abortion. * Charles Hines – 21 May 1897 – Hanged at Maitland for the rape of his thirteen-year-old stepdaughter Mary Emily Hayne at [[Gundy]] * Thomas Moore – 24 June 1897 – Hanged at Dubbo for the murder of 1897 – NEW SOUTH WALES. – Trove |publisher=Nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Moore|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/226750557|date=25 June 1897}}</ref> * Frank Butler – 17 July 1897 – ("The Glenbrook Murders") Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Arthur Preston and Lee Weller at Penrith and Glenbrook. * Wong Min – 13 December 1898 – Hanged at Dubbo for the murder of Joe Mong Jong (or Woung) at [[Warren, New South Wales]] on 16 August 1898. Also stabbed Alice Spong during same incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14190108 |title=14 Dec 1898 – THE WARREN MURDER. – Trove |publisher=Nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Stewart Wilson Christopher Briggs – 5 April 1899 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Margaret Miller and Margaret Dutt at 89 Douglas St [[Petersham, New South Wales|Petersham]] (now Stanmore).<ref>{{cite news|title=The Petersham Murder|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/99728391|publisher=Albury Banner & Wodonga Express|date=7 April 1899}}</ref>
===NSW part nine, 1900-1909 (12 listed)===
* John Sleigh (''alias'' Ward) – 6 December 1900 – Hanged at Goulburn for the murder of Frank "Bones" Curran at Back Creek, near [[Bombala, New South Wales|Bombala]]. * Jackie Underwood – 14 January 1901 – Indigenous. Hanged at Dubbo for the murder of Percival Mawbey at Breelong. He and Jimmy Governor also killed Helen Josephine Kerz, Mrs Sarah Mawbey, Grace Mawbey and Hilda Mawbey in the same incident.<ref name="capitalpunishmentuk.org"/> * [[Jimmy Governor]] – 18 January 1901 – Indigenous. Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Helen Josephine Kerz at Breelong. In the same incident he and Jackie Underwood also killed Mrs. Sarah Mawbey, Grace Mawbey, Percival Mawbey and Hilda Mawbey. Jimmy and his brother Joe also killed Alexander McKay near Ulan, Elizabeth O'Brien and her baby son at Poggie, near Merriwa, and Keiran Fitzpatrick near Wollar.<ref name="capitalpunishmentuk.org"/> * Joseph Campbell – 20 December 1901 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the rape of nine-year-old Violet Oldfield at [[Queanbeyan]]. He had also raped another nine-year-old at Ramsay's Bush (Haberfield) * Thomas Moore – 14 April 1903 – Indigenous. Hanged at Darlinghurst for the rape and murder of ten-year-old Janet Irene Smith at Ramsay's Bush, [[Leichhardt, New South Wales|Leichhardt]] (now Haberfield). * Digby Grand – 7 July 1903 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Police Constable Samuel Long at [[Auburn, New South Wales|Auburn]]. * Henry Jones – 7 July 1903 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Police Constable Samuel Long at [[Auburn, New South Wales|Auburn]]. * Ah Check – 28 June 1904 – Hanged at Dubbo for the murder of William Tregaskis at [[Peak Hill, New South Wales|Peak Hill]], NSW.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71511246?searchTerm=hanging ah check&searchLimits=l-state=New+South+Wales]</ref> He was the last person executed at Old Dubbo Gaol.<ref name="dailyliberal.com.au"/> * John Raymond Brown – 11 December 1906 – Hanged at [[Grafton Correctional Centre|Grafton Gaol]] for the murders of Daniel O'Keefe, Margaret O'Keefe and Patrick Gillick at German Creek, near [[Ballina, New South Wales|Ballina]] (now called Empire Vale). * Peter Sadeek – 11 June 1907 – Hanged at [[Broken Hill Correctional Centre|Broken Hill Gaol]] for the murder of Mary Cooney (or Jewson) at [[White Cliffs, New South Wales|White Cliffs]]. * Nicholas Baxter – 29 October 1907 – Hanged at Darlinghurst for the murder of Mary MacNamara at 2 Sarah St [[Enmore, New South Wales|Enmore]]. * George Toffts – 26 November 1907 – Hanged at [[Tamworth Correctional Centre|Tamworth Gaol]] for the murder of Eliza Maud Fletcher at [[Quirindi, New South Wales|Quirindi]].
===NSW part ten, 1910-19 (5 listed - complete)===
* William Frederick Ball – 17 June 1912 – Hanged at Armidale Gaol for the murder of Louisa Ball at [[Bingara, New South Wales|Bingara]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Centenary of the 1912 execution|url=http://starcommunity.com.au/armidale-independent/2012-06-13/final-drop-centenary-of-the-1912-execution/|publisher=Armidale Independent|date=13 June 2012}}</ref> * [[Sydney Twelve|Frank Franz]] – 20 December 1916 – Hanged at Bathurst for the murder of Police Constable George Joss Duncan at [[Tottenham, New South Wales|Tottenham]], NSW. * [[Sydney Twelve|Roland Nicholas Kennedy]] – 20 December 1916 – Hanged at Bathurst for the murder of Police Constable George Joss Duncan at Tottenham, NSW. * James Wilson – 31 May 1917 – Hanged at [[Long Bay Gaol]] for the murder of George Pappageorgi at [[Haymarket, New South Wales|Haymarket]], NSW. * Christian William Benzing – 16 June 1917 – Hanged at Long Bay for the rape and murder of eleven-year-old Dorothy Myra Small at [[Rockdale, New South Wales|Rockdale]].
===NSW part eleven, 1920 onwards (list is complete)===
* Edward Williams – 29 April 1924 – Hanged at Long Bay for the murder of his three children, five-year-old Rosalie, three-year-old Mary and two-year-old Cecillia at Underwood St [[Paddington, New South Wales|Paddington]], NSW. * William George Gordon Simpson – 10 December 1924 – Hanged at Long Bay for the murders of Guy Chalmers Clift and Police Constable James Flynn at [[Appin, New South Wales|Appin]]. * William Cyril Moxley – 17 August 1932 – Hanged at Long Bay for the murders of Dorothy Ruth Denzel and Frank Barnby Wilkinson at [[Moorebank, New South Wales|Moorebank]]. * Edwin John Hickey – 14 May 1936 – Hanged at Long Bay for the murder of former Conciliation Commissioner Montague Henwood on the train between Faulconbridge and [[Linden, New South Wales|Linden]]. Hickey was seventeen at the time of the crime. * James Leighton Massey – 15 June 1936 – Hanged at Long Bay for the murder of Norman Samuel McLaren Stead at [[Darlinghurst, New South Wales|Darlinghurst]]. * Alfred Spicer – 26 May 1938 – Hanged at Long Bay for the rape and murder of six-year-old Marcia Hayes at [[Windsor, New South Wales|Windsor]], NSW.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spicer Hanged|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/17468747|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=27 May 1938}}</ref> * John Trevor Kelly – 24 August 1939 – Hanged at Long Bay for the murder of Marjorie Constance Sommerlad at [[Tenterfield, New South Wales|Tenterfield]], NSW. He was the last person to be judicially executed in the state of New South Wales.<ref>[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11237909?searchTerm=John+Trevor+Kelly Murderer Hanged]</ref>

==Northern Territory== * Charles Flannagan – 15 July 1893 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murder of Samuel Croker at Auvergne Station. * Wandy Wandy – 25 July 1893 – Hanged on gallows constructed at the scene of the crime at Malay Bay for his part in the murder of six unnamed Malays. * Moolooloorun (Aboriginal male, no given surname) – 17 January 1895 – Hanged on gallows constructed at Crescent Lagoon in the presence of other members of his aboriginal community for the murder of an unnamed Chinese man near the Roper River. * Chung Yeung – 10 August 1899 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murder of Chee Hang at Yam Creek. * Lem Kai – 10 August 1899 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murder of Chee Hang at Yam Creek. * Jimmie (Aboriginal male, no given surname) – 8 April 1901 – Hanged on gallows constructed at Shaw's Creek, Victoria River, for the murder of John Larsen at Daly River. * Tommy (Aboriginal male, no given surname) – 21 December 1905 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murders of Henry Edwards, Richard Frost and Nowra at Victoria River district. * Koppio (Aboriginal male, no given surname) – 15 July 1913 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murders of Ching Loy and Lo Sin at the old Howley Mine. * Jaroslav Koci – 8 August 1952 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murder of Darwin taxi-driver George Thomas Grantham. * Jan Novotny – 8 August 1952 – Hanged at Fannie Bay Gaol for the murder of Darwin taxi-driver George Thomas Grantham.
==Queensland== * John Bulbridge – 18 December 1830 – Hanged at Moreton Bay for absconding from the penal colony there and committing a robbery at Port Macquarie<ref>THE RUNAWAY CONVICTS OF MORETON BAY By MAMIE O'KEEFFE, p. 57 https://espace.library.uq.edu.au/view/UQ:204799/s00855804_1975_76_10_1_52.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32074600 |title=01 Dec 1830 – Domestic Intelligence. – Trove |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Charles Fagan - 18 December 1830 - Hanged at Moreton Bay for absconding and committing a robbery at Port Macquarie * Mullan – 3 July 1841 – Indigenous. Hanged at the Windmill, Wickham Terrace, Brisbane, for the murder of surveyor Granville Chetwynd Stapylton at Mount Lindsay<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boggoroadgaol.com.au/2015/10/hangings-in-brisbane-1830-82.html |title=Inside Boggo Road: Hangings in Brisbane 1830–82 |publisher=Boggoroadgaol.com.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Ningavil - 3 July 1841 - Indigenous. Hanged at the Windmill, Wickham Terrace, Brisbane, for the murder of surveyor Granville Chetwynd Stapylton at Mount Lindsay * Patrick Fitzgerald - 8 July 1850 - Hanged in front of Brisbane Gaol, Petrie Terrace, for the murder of James Marsden at Gigooman * Jacob Wagner – 8 July 1850 – Hanged in front of Brisbane Gaol for the murder of James Marsden at Gigooman<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3712180 |title=08 Jul 1850 – Execution – Trove |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article12916907 |title=05 Apr 1850 – WIDE BAY. – Trove |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Angee (An Gee) – 6 January 1852 – Chinese. Hanged in front of Brisbane Gaol for the murder of James Holbert in the Burnett district<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3715329 |title=06 Jan 1852 – AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM. – Trove |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Davy – 22 August 1854 – Indigenous. Hanged in front of Brisbane Gaol for the murder of Adolphus Trevethan on Rawbelle station in the Burnett district<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3713054 |title=26 Aug 1854 – IPSWICH CONGREGATIONAL CHURCH. – Trove |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2016-12-07}}</ref> * Dundalli – 5 January 1855 – Indigenous. Hanged in front of Brisbane Gaol for the murders of Andrew Gregor and William Boller. Hanged at Boggo Road Gaol for the murder of Peter Dana (Dina, Dinna) at Innisfail *[[Ernest Austin (murderer)|Ernest Austin]]- 22 September 1913 – Hanged at Boggo Road Gaol for the murder of Ivy Alexandra Mitchell. He was the last person executed in Queensland<ref>http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article19905139?searchTerm=Ernest%20Austin&searchLimits=l-state=Queensland|||l-title=16</ref>
==South Australia== [[File:First Execution in South Australia, in 1838, for shooting Sheriff Smart.jpg|thumb|Pencil on paper sketch of the execution of Michael Magee. He was the first man executed in South Australia, for shooting Sheriff Smart.Artwork is inscribed, "Sketched on the ground by J. M. Skipper" which suggests the artist witnessed the execution. Artwork is inscribed with pencil on verso, with two figures of women. The costume worn by each figure has been carefully studied Held at the State Library of South Australia, call no. B 7797.]] *Michael Magee – 2 May 1838 – The first public execution in South Australia. A runaway convict, hanged on Montefiore Hill for shooting at with intent to kill Sheriff Smart<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution of Magee|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/31749933|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=South Australian Gazette and Colonial Register|date=19 May 1838|location=Adelaide|page=8}}</ref> *Wang Nucha (Tommy Roundhead) – 31 May 1839 – Hanged for the murder of James Thompson on the Para *Yerr-i-Cha (George) – 31 May 1839 – Hanged for the murder of William Duffield in the Gilles Plains area *George Hughes – 16 March 1840 – Hanged outside the Horse Police Barracks for theft and firing with murderous intent at the Para River *Henry Curran – 16 March 1840 – Hanged outside the Horse Police Barracks for theft and firing with murderous intent at the Para River *Mongarawata – 25 August 1840 – Hanged by Major O'Halloran on the Coorong in retribution for the massacre of over fifteen passengers wrecked on the [[Maria (brigantine)|''Maria'']] *Pilgarie (Moorcan-gac) – 25 August 1840 – Hanged by Major O'Halloran on the Coorong in retribution for the massacre of fifteen passengers wrecked on the ''Maria'' *Joseph Stagg – 18 November 1840 - Hanged for the murder of John Gofton near Torrens Island. The first public execution to be conducted outside [[Adelaide Gaol]], with a crowd of roughly seven hundred in attendance. *Ngarbi (Nultia) – 1 August 1843 – Hanged outside Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Elizabeth Stubbs at Port Lincoln *Wera Maldera – 28 March 1845 – Hanged outside Adelaide Gaol for the murder of George McGrath at McGrath's Flat, on the Coorong *Thomas Donnelly – 29 March 1847 – Hanged outside Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Kingberrie, an indigenous local, at [[Rivoli Bay]] *Keelgulla – 9 November 1849 – Hanged at the scene of the crime for the murder of Captain James Beevor at Mount Drummond *Neulalta – 9 November 1849 – Hanged at the scene of the crime for the murder of Captain James Beevor at Mount Drummond *James Yates – 5 September 1850 – Hanged outside Adelaide Gaol for the murder of a shepherd named Jack Mansforth at Skillagolee Creek *William Wright – 12 March 1853 – Hanged outside Adelaide Gaol for the murder of a man known as Robert Head, committed at East Wellington *William Bell – 27 December 1854 – Hanged outside Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Augustus Valrecht at Port Adelaide. This was the last public execution at Adelaide Gaol, with approximately three thousand onlookers. *Weenpulta – 14 January 1856 – Hanged at Franklin Harbour for the murder of Peter Brown<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution Of The Blacks At Franklin Harbour|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49752632|accessdate=3 February 2016|publisher=South Australian Register|date=21 January 1856}}</ref> *Weellanna – 14 January 1856 – Hanged at Franklin Harbour for the murder of Peter Brown *Yardulunulkarna – 14 January 1856 – Hanged at Franklin Harbour for the murder of Peter Brown *Eelanna – 14 January 1856 – Hanged at Franklin Harbour for the murder of Peter Brown *Manyetta – 5 October 1860 – Hanged at [[Streaky Bay, South Australia|Streaky Bay]] for the murder of John Jones at Mount Joy *Pilti Miltinda (Bobby) – 7 June 1861 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Mary Ann Rainberd (sometimes Reinbert) and her two children near [[Kapunda]] *Tankaworty (Alick ''or'' Jimmy) – 7 June 1861 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Mary Ann Rainberd and her two children near [[Kapunda]] *Warretya (Kop Robert) – 7 June 1861 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Mary Ann Rainberd and her two children near [[Kapunda]] *Warretya (Gogeye Jimmy) – 7 June 1861 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Mary Ann Rainberd and her two children near [[Kapunda]] *Nilgerie – 1861 – Hanged near the scene of the crime at Fowler's Bay for the murder of Thomas Berggoist *Tilcherie – 1861 – Hanged near the scene of the crime at Fowler's Bay for the murder of Thomas Berggoist *Mangiltie – 1861 – Hanged at Port Lincoln for the murder of Margaret Impey (Impett) at Mount Wedge *Karabidnie – 1861 – Hanged at Port Lincoln for the murder of Margaret Impey at Mount Wedge *John Seaver – 11 March 1862 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Police Inspector Richard Pettinger at a ball at [[Government House, Adelaide|Government House]], Adelaide *Magnultie – 1862 – Hanged at Venus Bay for the murder of William Walker near Cherado *[[Malachi Martin (Australian murderer)|Malachi Martin]] – 24 December 1862 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Jane Macmanamin at [[Salt Creek, South Australia|Salt Creek]] *Carl Jung – 10 November 1871 – Hanged at Mount Gambier for the murder of Assistant Bailiff Thomas Garraway at Deep Gully, near [[Mount Gambier, South Australia|Mount Gambier]] *[[Elizabeth Woolcock]] – 30 December 1873 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Thomas Woolcock at North Yelta. The only woman executed in South Australia. *William Ridgeway – 1 January 1874 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Frederick Burt at Coonatto<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution Of Ridgeway|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70471708|publisher=Australian Town and Country Journal|date=17 January 1874}}</ref> *William Page – 27 October 1875 – Hanged at Mount Gambier for the murder of Mary Julia Buchan<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution And Confession Of William Page|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article159483605|publisher=Adelaide Observer|date=30 October 1875}}</ref> *Charles Streitman - 24 July 1877 - Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Robert Woodhead at [[Wallaroo, South Australia|Wallaroo]] *Hugh Fagan (''alias'' James Lynch) - 15 April 1878 - Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Patrick Bannon at Saltire *Jonathan Prest - 16 July 1878 - Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of his wife Mary Prest near Port Adelaide<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution Of Jonathan Prest|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article160112113|publisher=Adelaide Observer|date=20 July 1878}}</ref> *Robert Johnson (''alias'' William Nugent) – 18 November 1881 – Hanged at Mount Gambier for the murder of Trooper Harry Pearce<ref>{{cite web|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/909747?searchTerm=Robert+Johnson |title=South Australia|work=The Brisbane Courier|date=19 November 1881 |accessdate=2010-09-12}}</ref> *William Burns – 18 January 1883 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Henry Loton on the high seas, off the Cape Verde Islands. "While waiting his doom, he formed an attachment to a young sparrow, which he tamed perfectly. He was greatly affected by the sight of the bird flitting about the scaffold while the preparations for his execution were in progress"<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution At Adelaide|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/150428660|publisher=Geelong Advertsier|date=20 Jan 1883}}</ref> *Mah Poo (''alias'' Charlie Bow) – 10 November 1883 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Tommy Ah Fook in Hindley Street<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution Of Mah Poo|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article198384792|publisher=Evening Journal|date=10 November 1883}}</ref> *William Brown (''alias'' Allen, ''alias'' Lane)– 24 August 1894 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of George Morowsky at [[Waukaringa, South Australia|Waukaringa]] *George Lynch – 6 November 1895 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Donald Ross at [[Balaklava, South Australia|Balaklava]] *Joshua Beard – 10 July 1897 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Walter Hall at [[Streaky Bay, South Australia|Streaky Bay]] *Lolli Kayser Singh – 17 January 1900 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Sunda Singh at [[Denial Bay]] *Thomas Horton – 12 May 1904 - Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of his wife Florence in Rundle Street *Albert Bonfield – 5 January 1905 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Caroline Hinds at [[Kensington Gardens, South Australia|Kensington Gardens]]<ref>{{cite news|title=The Kensington Murder|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article162424923|publisher=Observer (Adelaide)|date=7 January 1905}}</ref> *Notella Habibulla – 16 November 1906 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of his wife Edith in Bristol Street (off Cardwell St) *James (Joe) Coleman – 2 July 1908 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Constable Albert Ring at [[Glenelg, South Australia|Glenelg]] *John Robins – 16 March 1910 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Robert Ownsworth in Moonta St Adelaide *Hadji Khan – 5 April 1910 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Said Mahommed at Frome Creek *Carlos Augustus Bonello – 5 May 1910 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Norma Plush at Siegersdorf *Percival Budd – 24 April 1919 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Harold Jacques at [[Crystal Brook, South Australia|Crystal Brook]] *Alexander Newland Lee – 15 July 1920 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of his wife Muriel at [[Rhynie, South Australia|Rhynie]]. Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Thyra Bowman *[[Glen Sabre Valance]] – 24 November 1964 – Hanged at Adelaide Gaol for the murder of Richard Stang at Kooroon Station. Hanged at [[Fremantle Prison]]:<ref>{{cite web |title=Capital Punishment |url=http://www.fremantleprison.com.au/History/themodernera/capitalpunishment/Pages/default.aspx |website=Fremantle Prison |accessdate=20 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6TXKRF8b8?url=http://www.fremantleprison.com.au/History/themodernera/capitalpunishment/Pages/default.aspx the [[Lagrange Bay|La Grange Bay]] pearling grounds, near Broome, on 19 October 1899<ref name=ethel/> * Samuel Peters – 9 September 1902 – Hanged for the murder of his wife Trevenna Peters at September 1902|page=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Leederville Murder – Trial of Samuel Peters|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article24751941|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The West |accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The West Australian|date=5 February 1903|location=Perth, WA|page=5}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Smith's Mill news|title=The Waroona Murder|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/25715967|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=The west Australian|date=24 October 1907|page=7}}</ref> * Harry G. Smith – 23 March 1908 – Hanged for the murder of William John Clinton at Day Dawn on 5 January 1908 * Iwakichi Oki – 22 October 1908 – Hanged for the murder of James Henry Shaw at West Murray, Pinjarra on 23 August 1908 * [[Martha Rendell]] – 6 October 1909 – Hanged for the murder of her 14-year-old stepson Arthur Morris by poisoning on 8 October 1908, suspected of killing two younger stepchildren * Peter Robustelli – 9 February 1910 – Hanged for the murder of Giovanni Forsatti in a lane between Bayley and Woodward streets, Coolgardie on 19 October 1909<ref>{{cite news|title=Execution at Fremantle|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/69952740|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=Albany Advertiser|date=12 February 1910|page=3}}</ref> * Alexander Smart – 7 March 1911 – Hanged for the murder of Ethel May Harris at 5 Cowle Street, West Perth on 10 March 1910 * David H Smithson – 25 July 1911 – Hanged for the rape and murder of 18-year-old Elizabeth Frances Compton at Woodlupine on 13 May 1911 * Charles Spargo – 1 July 1913 – Hanged for the murder of Gilbert Pickering Jones at Broome on 23 January 1913<ref>{{cite news|title=Spargo's End|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article57748879|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=Sunday Times|date=6 July 1913|location=Perth, WA}}</ref> * Charles H. Trefene – 25 October 1926 – Hanged for the murders of [[Walsh and Pitman|Inspector John Walsh and Sergeant Alexander Pitman]] near Boulder on 28 April 1926<ref name=coulter/> * John Sumpter Milner – 21 May 1928 – Hanged for the rape and murder of 11-year-old Ivy Lewis at [[Darkan, Western Australia|Darkan]] on 28 February 1928<ref>{{cite news|title=Darkan Murder – John Milner Hanged|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/page/7927815 |accessdate=5 February 2017|date=21 May 1928|work=Daily News|location=Perth, WA|page=1}}</ref> * Clifford Hulme – 3 September 1928 – Hanged for the murder of Harold Eaton Smith at Wubin on 22 June 1928<ref>{{cite news|title=Wubin Murder Case – Clifford Hulme Executed|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article34435818|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=Western Argus|date=11 September 1928|location=Kalgoorlie, WA|page=27}}</ref> * Antonio Fanto – 18 May 1931 – Hanged for the murder of Cosimo Xesci at Latham on 20 March 1931<ref>{{cite news|title=The Latham Murder – Execution of Fanto|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article32520162|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The West Australian|date=19 May 1931|location=Perth, WA|page=14}}</ref> * John Thomas Smith ([[The Murchison Murders|Snowy Rowles]]) – 13 June 1932 – Hanged for the murder of Louis George Carron near the 183 mile gate on the No. 1 [[Rabbit-proof fence]], near [[Youanmi]], on or about 20 May 1930 * Karol Tapci – 23 June 1952 – Hanged for the murder of Norman Alfred Perfect at Wubin on 17 March<ref>{{cite news|title=Karol Tapci Hangs for Wubin Murder|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article49038062|accessdate=19 November 2015|work=The West Australian|date=24 June 1952|location=Perth, WA|page=1}}</ref> * Robert Jeremiah Thomas – 18 July 1960 – Hanged for the murder of taxi-driver Keith Mervyn Campbell Wedd at Claremont on 22 June 1959. Also charged with the murder of John and Kaye O'Hara in Jimbell St, Mosman Park.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man executed in Perth|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1300&dat=19600719&id=Q55VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Sa8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2795,3040178|accessdate=20 November 2015|work=The Age|date=19 July 1960|location=Melbourne, Vic.|page=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Killer's brother says he is being victimised |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19600715&id=b_pjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HuYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2618,10609177|accessdate=20 November 2015|work=Sydney Morning Herald|date=15 July 1960|page=6}}</ref><ref name=purdue54>{{cite book|last1=Purdue|first1=Brian|title=Legal Executions in Western Australia|date=1993|publisher=Foundation Press|isbn=9781875778003|pages=54–55}}</ref> * Mervyn Fallows – 6 June 1961 – Hanged for the rape and murder of 11-year-old Sandra Dorothea Smith at North Beach on or before 29 December 1960<ref name=purdue54/> * Brian William Robinson – 20 January 1964 – Hanged for the murder of Constable Noel Ileson at Belmont on 9 February 1963<ref name=purdue54/> * [[Eric Edgar Cooke]] – 26 October 1964 – Hanged for murder of John Lindsay Sturkey at Nedlands on 27 January 1963<ref name=purdue54/>

revision.text:
'''Meatless Monday''' is an international campaign that encourages people to not eat meat on [[Monday]]s to improve their [[Meat#Health|health]] and the [[Environmental effects of meat production|health of the planet]].
Meatless Monday is a non-profit initiative of The Monday Campaigns Inc. in association with the [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]] [[Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future|Center for a Livable Future]]. Meatless Monday was founded in 2003 by marketing professional Sid Lerner. The program follows the nutrition guidelines developed by the USDA.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mypyramid.gov/ |title=United States Department of Agriculture - Home |publisher=MyPyramid.gov |date=2010-03-24 |accessdate=2010-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070726014831/http://www.mypyramid.gov/ |archivedate=2007-07-26 |df= }}</ref> Meatless Monday is part of the Healthy Monday initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.healthymonday.org/ |title=Healthy Monday |publisher=Healthy Monday |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> Healthy Monday encourages Americans to make healthier decisions at the start of every week. Other Healthy Monday campaigns include: The Kids Cook Monday, Monday 2000, Quit and Stay Quit Monday, Move it Monday, The Monday Mile, and others.
Meatless Monday focuses its initiative on Mondays for several reasons. Friday is traditionally already a meat-free day among Catholics and Orthodox. Monday is typically the beginning of the work week, the day when individuals settle back into their weekly routine. Habits that prevailed over the weekend can be forgotten and replaced by other choices.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mondaycampaigns.org/about/research/ |title= The Science behind The Monday Campaigns |website= The Monday Campaigns |quote= Health promotions at the beginning of the week have the potential to reduce negative health events. There’s a spike in heart problems, occupational injuries, strokes, suicides and referrals to secondary care on Monday, which researchers believe is caused by stress, unhealthy weekend behaviors and disruption of sleep cycles.}}</ref> A weekly reminder to restart healthy habits also encourages success. A 2009 trial published in the American Journal of Preventive Medicine provided individuals with weekly health prompts and encouragement. Approximately two thirds of participants responded with improvements in their overall health, eating habits and physical activity levels.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/05/19/BA4917MKAP.DTL&type=health |title=Trial: E-nagging can increase healthy activity |publisher=Sfgate.com |date=2009-05-19 |accessdate=2010-05-05 | first=Victoria | last=Colliver}}</ref>
== History == During [[World War I]], President [[Woodrow Wilson]] issued a proclamation calling for every Tuesday to be meatless and for one meatless meal to be observed every day, for a total of nine meatless meals each week.<ref>{{cite news |last= Wilson |first= Woodrow |author-link= Woodrow Wilson |date= 1918-01-18 |title= President's Proclamation Calling Upon People of Nation to Reduce Consumption of Wheat and Meat Products in Order to Feed America's Associates in the War |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=LW49AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PR10 |editor-last= Rochester |editor-first= Edward S. |newspaper= Official Bulletin |volume= 2 |issue= 219 |location= [[Washington, D.C.]] |publisher= United States [[Committee on Public Information]] |publication-date= 1918-01-28 |page= 3 |quote= In both homes and public eating places, in order to reduce the consumption of beef, pork, and sheep products, Tuesday should be observed as meatless day in each week, one meatless meal should be observed in each day, while, in addition, Saturday in each week should further be observed as a day upon which there should be no consumption of pork products.}}</ref> The [[United States Food Administration]] (USFA) urged families to reduce consumption of key staples to help the war effort and avoid rationing. Conserving food would support U.S. troops as well as feed populations in Europe where food production and distribution had been disrupted by war. To encourage voluntary rationing, the USFA created the slogan “Food Will Win the War” and coined the terms "Meatless Tuesday" and "Wheatless Wednesday” to remind Americans to reduce intake of those products.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecommcode.com/hoover/hooveronline/hoover_bio/archive/food/wheat.htm |title=Wheatless Wednesdays |publisher=Hoover Museum - Digital Archives |date= |accessdate=December 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911213710/http://www.ecommcode.com/hoover/hooveronline/hoover_bio/archive/food/wheat.htm |archivedate=September 11, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
[[Herbert Hoover]] was the head of the Food Administration as well as the American Relief Association during Woodrow Wilson's presidency, and played a key role implementing the campaign, which was one of Hoover’s many attempts to encourage volunteerism and sacrifice among Americans during the war. The USFA provided a wide variety of materials in addition to advertising, including recipe books and menus found in magazines, newspapers and government-sponsored pamphlets.<ref>http://exhibits.mannlib.cornell.edu/meatlesswheatless/images/large/Foods%20That%20Will%20Win%20115.jpg</ref>
The campaign returned with the onset of [[World War II]], calling upon women on the home front to play a role in supporting the war effort. During this time, meat was being rationed, along with other commodities like sugar and gasoline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.u-s-history.com/pages/h1674.html |title=World War II Rationing |publisher=U-s-history.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> The [[Harry Truman]] administration, through the Citizens Food Committee, encouraged "Meatless Tuesdays" and "Poultryless Thursdays" throughout the autumn of 1947; backlash was swift, noncompliance was rampant, and the poultry lobby responded with the [[National Thanksgiving Turkey Presentation]], the forerunner of the modern "turkey pardon."<ref>https://dinersjournal.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/23/the-way-we-ate-the-year-harry-truman-passed-on-pumpkin-pie/</ref>
Meatless Monday was restarted in 2003 as a public health awareness program. The campaign was endorsed by the Center for a Livable Future (a division of the [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]]) as well as over 20 public health schools. In April 2009, Meatless Monday launched an informational video noting the [[effects of meat consumption on climate change]].{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}
Meatless Monday is based in the United States, but meatless days (Monday in particular) are gaining popularity worldwide. Meat-free Mondays exist in the United Kingdom both as an advertising campaign for Goodlife Foods and as an environmental campaign.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goodlife.co.uk/index.htm |title=Goodlife Vegetarian Foods: Home Page |publisher=Goodlife.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815113841/http://www.goodlife.co.uk/index.htm |archivedate=2009-08-15 |df= }}</ref> On June 15, 2009 [[Paul McCartney]] and his daughters Stella and Mary launched a Meat-free Monday campaign. In October 2009, Meatless Monday was launched in São Paulo with government support by the Brazilian Vegetarian Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.segundasemcarne.com.br/Segunda|title=Segunda Sem Carne agora é lei no DF|work=segundasemcarne.com.br|accessdate=31 August 1980}}</ref> In December 2009, Meatless Mondays launched in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meatlessmondays-australia.com |title=Meatless Mondays Australia |publisher=Meatless Mondays Australia |date=2010-04-26 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref>
In May 2009, the city of [[Ghent]], Belgium became the first city with 'official' weekly vegetarian days. Veggie Thursday (or "Donderdag Veggiedag” in Dutch) was created by the Ethical Vegetarian Alternative, an organization partially funded by the Flemish government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vegetarisme.be/ |title=Actueel â€˘ EVA, verleidelijk vegetarisch |publisher=Vegetarisme.be |date=2010-04-05 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> Israeli magazine ''Al Hashulchan'' (On the Table) introduced the Sheni Tzimchoni (Vegetarian Monday) initiative in June 2009. Dozens of Israel’s top restaurants will create innovative meatless meals on Mondays throughout July and August 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hashulchan.co.il/Index.asp?ArticleID=12763&CategoryID=346&Page=1|title=על השולחן - בישול, אוכל, מתכונים|publisher=Hashulchan.co.il|date=|accessdate=2010-05-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091201213610/http://www.hashulchan.co.il/Index.asp?ArticleID=12763&CategoryID=346&Page=1|archivedate=2009-12-01|df=}}</ref> On April 6, 2010, San Francisco became the first US city to officially declare Mondays to be "meat free", calling it their Vegetarian Day. Several other countries have meat-free days as well, including Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meatlessmonday.ca |title=Meatless Monday}}</ref>
In March 2012, the [[Government of Croatia]] also supported the initiative, excluding meat from the menu of the [[Ministry of Environment and Nature Protection]] on Mondays.
In 2017, the [[Casa Rosada]] of Argentina instituted, for one lunch of the day, meat-free Mondays, serving only vegan options to its approximately 500 employees, including President [[Mauricio Macri]].<ref name="veconomist" >{{cite news|author=A.L.|title=Argentina’s vegan Mondays|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2017/10/economist-explains-13|work=[[The Economist]]|date=19 October 2017}}</ref>
==Opposition==
An attempt by the Greens in Brighton, England, to initiate Meat-Free Mondays, thereby stopping the local council cafeteria selling any meat based foods, was halted after opposition from council workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theargus.co.uk/news/9165595.Brighton_and_Hove_binmen_get____meat_free_Monday____the_chop/ |title=Brighton and Hove binmen get "meat-free Monday" the chop |publisher=Brighton Argus |date=2011-07-28 |accessdate=2011-09-03}},/</ref>
==Press timeline==
*''[[Woman's Day]]'' magazine has included Meatless Monday on their monthly recipe calendar since 2004. Each menu offers healthy meal options for four and includes a set weekly shopping list.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.womansday.com/Articles/Food/Month-of-Menus!.html |title=Month of Menus at WomansDay.com - Daily Recipes and Shopping List |publisher=Womansday.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> *From September 2008 to July 2009, Kim O’Donnel, a food journalist and trained cook, offered weekly Meatless Monday recipes in her ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' column “A Mighty Appetite”.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kim ODonnel |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/mighty-appetite/meatless_monday/ |title=A Mighty Appetite Archive by Category |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> *The Face on Your Plate: The Truth About Food,<ref>{{Cite book|isbn=0393065952 |title=The Face on Your Plate: The Truth About Food (9780393065954): Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date= }}</ref> written in March 2009 by [[Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/-/e/B000AP80DY |title=Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle |publisher=Amazon.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> acknowledged Meatless Monday as a way to reduce [[meat consumption]] and improve overall health. *Articles regarding Meatless Monday have been published by several authors in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' since April 2009. Notable contributor Kathy Freston is author of several self-help & wellness books, including The Quantum Wellness Cleanse.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/search.php/?q=Meatless+Monday |title= Search Results for Meatless Monday |work= [[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref> *In his book ''[[In Defense of Food]]'', journalist [[Michael Pollan]] coined the phrase "Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants." He has since cited Meatless Monday as a way to reach this goal. So in April 2009 Pollan expressed the need for Americans to reduce meat consumption on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'': "even one meatless day a week—a Meatless Monday, which is what we do in our household—if everybody in America did that, that would be the equivalent of taking 20 million mid-size sedans off the road."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/article/oprahshow/20090422-tows-pollan-omnivore/2 |title=Michael Pollan - Omnivore's Dilemma - Environment and Food |publisher=Oprah.com |date=2009-04-22 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> *Carole Carson, author and spokeswoman for [[AARP|AARP's]] “Fat 2 Fit” challenge, began offering Meatless Monday recipes to AARP’s online community in June 2009.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carson |first=Carole |url=http://www.aarp.org/health/healthyliving/fat2fit/ |title=Fat 2 Fit |publisher=Aarp.org |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> *In June 2009, the film [[Food, Inc.]] listed Meatless Monday as one of the 10 Things You Can Do To Change Our Food System.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foodincmovie.com/img/downloads/food_inc_5x7_v3.jpg|title=TakePart - Stories That Matter, Actions That Count|website=www.foodincmovie.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010155102/http://www.foodincmovie.com/img/downloads/food_inc_5x7_v3.jpg|archivedate=2009-10-10|df=}}</ref> *Also in June 2009 leading recipe site [[Epicurious]] teamed up with NutritionData.com to start offering weekly Meatless Monday recipes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nutritiondata.com/topics/recipes |title=Healthy dinner recipes with nutrition facts |publisher=Nutritiondata.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420164134/http://www.nutritiondata.com/topics/recipes |archivedate=2010-04-20 |df= }}</ref> *In July 2009, ''The Huffington Post Green'' began a weekly Meatless Monday recipe column. The articles are written by nationally syndicated columnist Ellen Kanner, The Edgy Veggie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ellen-ink.com/ |title=|||| Ellen Kanner |||| |publisher=Ellen-ink.com |date= |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> *Baltimore City Public Schools began a system-wide Meatless Monday program in 2009. The initiative also includes health education and produce from local sources. BCPS's efforts were acknowledged by Johns Hopkins University in September 2009, when they were given the Center for a Livable Future Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/green/bal-md.gr.lunch24sep24,0,1379910.story |title=Eat Hearty, Local |publisher=Baltimore Sun |date=2009-09-24 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jhsph.edu/publichealthnews/press_releases/2009/clf_event_farm |title=Baltimore City Public Schools Honored for Healthy Menu |publisher=Jhsph.edu |date=2009-09-29 |accessdate=2010-05-05}}</ref> *In December 2009, [[Al Gore]] formally endorsed the Meatless Monday campaign before EU Parliament. Gore now lists Meatless Monday as one of the Top 12 Things You Can Do Now for a better world on his Climate Crisis blog.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.climatecrisis.net/twelve-things-to-do.php |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101005075230/http://climatecrisis.net/twelve-things-to-do.php |archivedate= 2010-10-05 |title= 12 Things To Do |publisher= [[TakePart]] |quote= Try Meatless Mondays}}</ref> *Former [[Manhattan]] borough president [[Scott Stringer]] proposed that all [[New York City]] public schools switch to Meatless Monday in his Food NYC report on February 17, 2010.<ref>{{cite web |last= Stringer |first= Scott M. |authorlink= Scott Stringer |url= http://www.mbpo.org/uploads/foodnyc.pdf |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130906194745/http://urbanomnibus.net/redux/wp-content/uploads/2010/02/foodnyc.pdf |archivedate= 2013-09-06 |title= FoodNYC: A Blueprint for a Sustainable Food System |date= February 2010 |page= 24 |quote= Institute Meatless Mondays in City Schools}}</ref> Several NYC schools have followed the recommendation.<ref>{{cite web |last=Christ |first=Lindsey |url=http://manhattan.ny1.com/content/top_stories/114462/charter-school-cuts-the-fat--urges-others-to-join |title=Manhattan School Cuts The Fat; Urges Others To Join |publisher=NY1 |date=March 1, 2010 |accessdate=December 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101104091727/http://manhattan.ny1.com/content/top_stories/114462/charter-school-cuts-the-fat--urges-others-to-join |archivedate=November 4, 2010 |df= }}</ref> *The [[San Francisco]] Board of Supervisors passed a Meatless Monday resolution on April 6, 2010 to “encourage restaurants, schools and grocery stores to offer plant-based options”.<ref name="abclocal1">{{cite web|last=Tyler |first=Carolyn |url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/san_francisco&id=7370993 |title=San Francisco supervisors approve meat-free Mondays |publisher=KGO-TV |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=December 31, 2011}}</ref> *On April 12, 2010, The [[Johns Hopkins Hospital]] launched Meatless Monday in their cafeteria.<ref name="abclocal1"/> *[[ABC Family]]'s teen TV Series ''[[10 Things I Hate About You]]'' aired an episode called "Meat is Murder" on April 19, 2010, where one of the lead characters, Kat, convinces her student council to launch Meatless Mondays in their high school cafeteria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcfamily.go.com/watch/10-things-i-hate-about-you/SH5524459/VD5551867/meat-is-murder |title=10 Things I Hate About You: "Meat is Murder" episode |publisher=ABC Family |date= |accessdate=December 31, 2011}}</ref> *Chef [[Mario Batali]] unveiled Meatless Monday menus in all 14 of his restaurants in April 2010. Each menu now includes two weekly features.<ref>{{cite news|last=Elam |first=Chris |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/chris-elam/mario-batali-meatless-mon_b_557589.html |title=Meatless Mondays: Even Mario Batali's Doing It |publisher=Huffington Post |date=May 3, 2010 |accessdate=December 31, 2011}}</ref> *''The Washington Post'' reported on the international growth of the campaign on May 19, 2010. The article details the rising Meatless Monday movement and the meat industry’s reaction.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/18/AR2010051800891.html | work=The Washington Post | title=Meatless Mondays, a movement that has legs | first=Jane | last=Black | date=2010-05-19}}</ref> *[[Fox News]]' Sunday Housecall with Dr. Isadore Rosenfeld aired a segment featuring Meatless Monday on July 25, 2010. He stated that recent studies showed meat consumption can impede weight loss. Dr. Rosenfeld presents a Healthy Monday tip on his show each week.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/4293311/healthy-monday-tip | work=Fox News | date=2010-09-29 | title=Healthy Monday Tip - Fox News Video - Fox News}}</ref> *On August 9, 2010, [[NPR]] conducted an interview with Sid Lerner, the founder of the Meatless Monday campaign, about the growing public awareness and support.<ref>{{cite web|last=Aubrey |first=Allison |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129025298 |title=Campaign Aims To Make Meatless Mondays Hip |publisher=NPR |date=August 9, 2010 |accessdate=December 31, 2011}}</ref> *''[[TIME magazine]]'' profiled six chefs that are creating [[flexitarian]] dishes in their August 23, 2010 issue. Included were Meatless Monday supporters [[Mario Batali]], [[Wolfgang Puck]] and John Fraser.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2010187,00.html | work=Time | title=Where's The Beet? | first=Joel | last=Stein | date=2010-08-23}}</ref> *[[Andrew Freeman & Co.]] included Meatless Monday in their ''2011 Trend List: 18 up-and-coming ideas that restaurateurs should be watching'', noting that “Meatless Mondays and vegetable based [[tasting menu]]s are gaining traction as guests realize it’s not all about the meat on the plate.”<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.hospitalityworldnetwork.com/operations/andrew-freeman-co-reveals-2011-trend-list-hospitality-9415|title=Andrew Freeman & Co. reveals 2011 hospitality trends|publisher=Hotel and Motel Management|date=October 26, 2010}}</ref> * Institutional feeder [[Sodexo]] announced in January 2011 that it would be offering Meatless Monday materials to more than 900 hospitals in their network.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://sodexousa.com/usen/media/press-releases/2011/meatlessmondayexpands041811.aspx |title= Sodexo More Than Triples Reach of Its Meatless Monday Offer |date= 2011-04-18 |publisher= [[Sodexo]] |quote= In the wake of a successful introduction of the Meatless Monday initiative to more than 900 hospitals nationwide, Sodexo, the world leader in quality of daily life solutions, is now extending it to more than 2000 corporate and government client locations in North America, including Toyota, Northern Trust Bank and the U.S. Department of the Interior.}}</ref> This effort was expanded in April 2011 when Sodexo provided materials to more than 2000 corporate and government client locations in North America, including Toyota, Northern Trust Bank and the U.S. Department of the Interior.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/sodexo-more-than-triples-reach-of-its-meatless-monday-offer-120055684.html |title= Sodexo More Than Triples Reach of its Meatless Monday Offer |date= 2011-04-18 |agency= [[PR Newswire]]}}</ref> *In February 2011 [[The Oprah Winfrey Show]] highlighted Meatless Monday in an episode on vegan living. [[Oprah Winfrey|Oprah]] declared that Meatless Monday options would be available in the [[Harpo Studios]] cafeteria. Oprah then asked her studio audience to take part in the campaign, saying “Meatless Monday is something you can do at home with your family if you choose”.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.oprah.com/oprahshow/Oprah-Goes-Vegan-Video/topic/oprahshow |title= Oprah Goes Vegan |date= 2011-02-01 |website= [[Oprah.com]] |format= video }}</ref> *A report by the American Meat Institute in February 2011 found that 18% of American households now participate in Meatless Mondays.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sustainablefoodnews.com/story.php?news_id=11948 |title= Survey shines light on consumer attitudes toward organic beef, poultry |date= 2011-02-23 |website= Sustainable Food News |location= [[Portland, Maine]]}}</ref> *In June 2011 Aspen, Colorado became the first official “Meatless Monday city” with over 20 local restaurants, Aspen Valley Hospital, Aspen Elementary School, The Aspen Club & Spa, and The University of Colorado School of Medicine participating.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.meatlessmonday.com/articles/meatless-monday-gains-momentum-in-communities-nationwide/ |title= Meatless Monday Gains Momentum in Communities Nationwide |date= 2013-04-15 |quote= In June 2011, ... Aspen, CO, became the nation’s first true Meatless Monday community}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Oksenhorn |first= Stewart |url=http://www.aspentimes.com/article/20110605/NEWS/110609905 |title= Take Monday off - from meat |date= 2011-06-05 |newspaper= [[The Aspen Times]]}}</ref> *A tracking study conducted by FGI research found that, as of May 23, 2011, U.S. awareness of the Meatless Monday campaign had reached 50.22% (up from 30% 6 months previously). Of those aware of Meatless Monday, 27.47% said the campaign had influenced their decision to cut back on meat. In response Meatless Monday launched their “get the other half” initiative, aimed at encouraging participants to tell their friends and family about the movement.<ref>{{cite news |last= Scott-Thomas |first= Caroline |url= http://www.foodnavigator-usa.com/Suppliers2/Meatless-Monday-campaign-reaches-more-than-half-of-America |title= Meatless Monday campaign reaches more than half of America |date= 2011-06-09 |agency= FoodNavigator-USA.com |publisher= [[William Reed Business Media]] |quote= Awareness of the 'Meatless Monday' campaign has reached more than half of Americans, according to an online tracking survey conducted by FGI Research. The poll found that 50.22 percent of 2,000 American adults in a nationally representative sample were aware of the campaign ... up from 30 percent awareness six months ago.}}</ref> *In March 2012, the [[Government of Croatia]] also supported the initiative, excluding meat from the menu of the Ministry of Environment and Nature Protection on Mondays. *In November 2012, the City of [[Los Angeles]] declared all Mondays to be "Meatless Mondays," citing actions by the [[Baltimore]] City Public School System, [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] Unified School District, along with other school districts in [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington]], VA, [[Oneida, New York|Oneida]], NY and [[Longmont, Colorado|Longmont]], CO, as well as the cities of [[San Francisco]], [[Takoma Park, Maryland|Takoma Park]], MD, and [[Annapolis]], MD, [[Marin County]], CA, and the Council of the [[Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]].<ref>{{cite news | last = Lowery | first = Wesley | title = City Council asks L.A. residents to go 'meatless' on Mondays | url = http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/11/city-council-asks-la-residents-to-go-meatless-on-mondays-.html?fb_action_ids=4850446379034&fb_action_types=og.recommends&fb_source=other_multiline&action_object_map={%224850446379034%22%3A463293137056148}&action_type_map={%224850446379034%22%3A%22og.recommends%22}&action_ref_map= | newspaper = Los Angeles Times | location = Los Angeles, CA | date = 2012-11-12 | accessdate = 2012-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Meatless Mondays | publisher = LACityClerk Connect | url = http://cityclerk.lacity.org/lacityclerkconnect/index.cfm?fa=ccfi.viewrecord&cfnumber=12-1721 | date = 2012-11-09 | accessdate = 2012-11-12}}</ref> *In October 23, 2017, Mayor Bill de Blasio, Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña and Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams announced that 15 Brooklyn schools will participate in Meatless Mondays starting spring of 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/675-17/mayor-de-blasio-chancellor-fari-a-borough-president-adams-15-brooklyn-schools-to |date= 2017-10-27 | accessdate=2017-10-27 | publisher = City of New York |title=Meatless Mondays in 15 NYC Schools}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/10/23/meatless-mondays-new-york-city/ | title=Students Dine On All-Veggie Menus As ‘Meatless Mondays’ Hit Some City Schools | date=2017-10-27 | accessdate=2017-10-23 | publisher= CBS New York}}</ref>
